selected_quotes: Testosterone concentrations significantly elevated in sessions that preceded winning games, but not the losses #sport
@SJSemple Salivary testosterone responses to mid-week workouts associated with outcomes in professional rugby league.
TESTOSTERONE CORTISOL ASSOCIATED w COMPETITION OUTCOMES IN PRO RUGBY #Rugby #Testosterone
“@lukerstorey: Can testosterone response predict match performance/outcome? yea but only on Tuesdays.

citation.abstract: This study assessed the responses of salivary-free testosterone (T) and cortisol (C) concentrations across selected training workouts and their association with the subsequent competition outcomes in professional rugby league. Thirteen rugby league players were assessed for salivary-free T and C concentrations across 5 training workouts performed 3-4 days before a competitive game. The game outcomes included wins and losses and game-ranked performance (1-5) based on the number of points scored, the points differential, and a coach rating. Data were pooled across the winning (n = 3) and losing (n = 2) outcomes. Pooled free T concentrations (absolute and relative changes) were significantly (p < 0.01) elevated across those workouts that preceded winning games, but not the losses, and the relative (percent) T changes were significantly (p < 0.05) higher before winning (30.9%) than before losing (3.4%). Both outcomes were associated with workout decreases in pooled free C concentrations and the relative C changes were not significantly different between wins (-22.9%) and losses (-25.6%). In conclusion, the free T responses to selected training workouts showed some association with subsequent winning (being elevated) and losing (no change) during a limited number of competitive games in professional rugby league. Speculatively, the free T responses to a midweek workout might provide an early sign of team readiness to compete or to recovery state, thereby providing a novel format for implementing training or management strategies to improve the competition outcomes.
citation.title: The workout responses of salivary free testosterone and cortisol concentrations and their association with the subsequent competition outcomes in professional rugby league.
